rationale: Distinct historical movement with clear name, description, and type; no other candidate refers to exactly the same concept.
Represents a specific calendar year; no other timepoint entity in the group to merge with.
Represents the specific initial protests in Tunisia, distinct from the broader Arab Spring movement.
Country-level location entity; no duplicate or overlapping Tunisia entity present.
Region-level location (Middle East), distinct from North Africa and the combined 'region' reference.
Region-level location (North Africa), distinct from Middle East and from the collective 'region' mention.
Event type (overthrows) that is conceptually distinct from the actors ('long-standing dictators') and the broader movement.
Role/actor category (authoritarian rulers) distinct from the overthrow events themselves.
Abstract concept (democratic change) with no duplicate abstract-concept entity in this group.
Refers anaphorically to the combined Middle East and North Africa; while related to the two region entities, it is not identical to either and is better kept separate to remain conservative.
Distinct historical political event (the 1917 Russian Revolution), not overlapping in type or scope with the other entities.
A specific political organization (the Bolsheviks), clearly separate from the event, person, dynasty, and resulting state.
A specific person (Vladimir Lenin), distinct from the revolution, the party, the dynasty, and the state entity.
A royal dynasty (the Romanov dynasty), conceptually different from the revolution, organization, leader, and new state.
Refers to the resulting communist state as an entity; even if it likely implies Soviet Russia, this is not explicit enough to justify merging or renaming.
Distinct geographic-historical location; no other entity in the group represents the same concept.
Represents a specific laborer group, clearly distinct from the location, structures, or the strike event itself.
Refers to the physical pyramid structures, which are conceptually different from workers, protest, or demands.
Denotes the collective action (strike event), not the workers, place, or demands; should remain separate.
Represents a specific demand (improved conditions), distinct from wages and other entities.
Captures the compensation aspect (wages), which is a separate economic concept from working conditions or the strike itself.
This clearly refers to the historical U.S. civil rights movement as a social and political movement, distinct from specific pieces of legislation.
This refers to a set of major civil rights laws in the 1960s, which are outcomes of the movement, so it should remain a separate legal-instrument entity.
Distinct, clearly identified historical person (American civil rights leader) with no overlapping identity with other entities.
Distinct, clearly identified historical person (American civil rights activist) separate from Martin Luther King Jr. and the abstract concept of discrimination.
Represents an abstract social concept (unfair treatment) and does not overlap with the two person entities; the type_hint is acceptable though somewhat broad.
Both mentions use the same phrase in the same historical-protest context and describe the early period of protest history.
Both refer to the same contemporary period contrasted with ancient times in the context of ongoing protest history.
This is a distinct concept (collective work stoppages as a protest tactic) and does not duplicate any other entity in the group.
Distinct historical political event (the French Revolution of 1789) clearly separated from institutions and principles it influenced.
Refers specifically to the French monarchy as a political institution, which is conceptually distinct from the revolution and the later republic.
Represents the republican form of government in France, a separate political institution from both the monarchy and the revolutionary event.
Denotes an ideological set of principles, not an event or institution, and thus should remain a separate entity.
Describes a broad class of revolutionary social movements inspired by the French Revolution, distinct from the French events and institutions themselves.
Refers specifically to the historical document, distinct from the principles and phrases it contains.
Represents a specific ideological principle/phrase from the document, not the document itself or other rights concepts.
Denotes the broader concept of inherent rights, distinct from the equality phrase and from the document as a whole.
Captures the more general set of principles influencing later movements, which is conceptually broader than any single phrase or right.
Specific historical event with clear description and type; no overlapping entity to merge with.
Distinct country entity; not duplicated elsewhere in this group.
Specific event in Belarus; no other entity represents the same event.
Represents a group of actors (pro-democracy protesters) distinct from any other entity in the group.
Distinct country entity; no other candidate refers to Belarus as a location.
Abstract condition (dissent), not overlapping with any other specific group or event entity.
Represents political/social opposition as an actor group; not clearly identical to any other entity.
Plural actor entity (governments) that is conceptually distinct from protesters and opposition groups.
Refers to the general goal/condition of equality, distinct from the other concepts mentioned.
Denotes a specific social process (a national conversation) and is not synonymous with the other entities.
Represents the social category of race, conceptually distinct from equality, inequality, and the conversation process.
Captures the condition of inequality, which is the opposite of equality and not mergeable with the other entities.
Distinct social/political movement with clear scope and description; no duplicates present.
Represents a general phenomenon (excessive force by police), distinct from movements, locations, and goals.
Represents a systemic social condition, not overlapping in identity with the other entities.
Clearly a country/location entity; no competing or duplicate United States entity in this group.
Represents a normative goal or concept (fair treatment regardless of race), distinct from the movement and conditions mentioned.
Both entities share the exact same name, refer to the same abstract idea in nearly identical contexts, and differ only in type_hint granularity.
Refers broadly to human societies affected by protests; no duplicate with matching scope in this group.
A specific historical time period; no other entity represents the same span with the same name.
A distinct time period (late 20th and early 21st centuries) not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Represents the general class of events 'protests and revolutions', which is conceptually distinct from the time periods and landscapes mentioned.
Refers to the global location/context ('the world'); no clear duplicate in this set.
Represents the general phenomenon of political/social repression, distinct from other entities.
Refers specifically to physical violence as a phenomenon, separate from repression and authorities.
Represents state or governmental actors; clearly distinct from the phenomena of repression and violence.
Refers broadly to socialist movements inspired by socialism after the Russian Revolution; no other entity in the group shares this scope or meaning.
Denotes a generic class of authoritarian governments targeted by movements; clearly distinct from socialist movements themselves and should not be merged.
Refers specifically to the overall trajectory of human events over time; distinct from specific types of change or particular historical topics.
Represents a general concept of societal or political alteration; broader and more generic than the other outcome-related entities.
Denotes deep or fundamental shifts, which is conceptually related to but not identical with generic 'change', so it should remain distinct.
Refers to the specific domain topic 'history of protests and revolutions', clearly distinct from abstract notions like change or history in general.
Captures a specific outcome type, 'social and political change', which is more specific than generic 'change' and should remain its own entity.
Refers broadly to the historical record of protests and revolutions over time, distinct from their specific legacy or metaphorical paths of progress.
A metaphorical process ('road to progress') conceptually separate from both the history and the legacy of protests and revolutions.
Focuses on the enduring impact or legacy of past protests and revolutions, which is related but not identical to their overall history or the metaphorical path of progress.
Refers specifically to political rights as a subtype of rights tied to participation and representation; distinct from the broader concept of rights.
Represents groups of individuals (actors) participating in protests; clearly distinct from abstract concepts like rights.
Represents rights in a broad, general sense; not identical to the more specific concept of political rights, so it should remain separate.
Refers specifically to the condition of injustice, distinct from equality and human rights as separate concepts.
Represents the abstract goal of equality, which is conceptually different from both injustice and human rights.
Denotes the distinct abstract concept of human rights, not interchangeable with injustice or equality.
Refers specifically to the abstract concept of injustice being challenged by protests; distinct from but related to oppression.
Refers to the broader systemic condition of oppression that people seek to overcome; not clearly identical to the concept of injustice in context.
Refers specifically to the U.S. civil rights movement, distinct from generic references to democracy, equality, or justice movements.
Represents general movements for democracy, not tied to a single specific historical movement.
Represents general movements for equality, conceptually separate from democracy and justice movements.
Represents general movements for justice, distinct from the democracy and equality movements and from the U.S. civil rights movement.
Both mentions describe the same underlying ideal of a fair and equitable society pursued through political struggle, differing only in phrasing rather than concept.
All mentions refer generically to political and social revolutions within the same discourse, differing only in granular type hints but clearly describing the same general concept.
Refers to the general class of large-scale uprisings, distinct from any specific revolution event.
Refers to a specific historical event (the American Revolution), not a general concept.
Represents the abstract concept of freedom, distinct from events, systems, or specific political goals.
Captures a specific political goal (achieving independence), not the abstract concept of freedom or the system of colonial rule itself.
Describes a governance system (colonial rule), distinct from the goal of ending it or the broader concept of freedom.
Distinct human attribute (resilience) with clear description and context; no other entity in the group refers to exactly the same concept.
Distinct human attribute (determination) that is conceptually related to but not identical with resilience, so it should remain separate.
Refers to normative concepts (rights and freedoms), clearly different in type and meaning from the human attributes; no merge or modification warranted.
Refers to non-elite individuals collectively; distinct from abstract concepts like accountability.
Refers to a normative concept about holding power to account, not a group of people; no overlap with 'ordinary people'.
Distinct, well-defined movement (Arab Spring) with no duplicate in the group.
Specific time point (year 2010) clearly distinct from other entities.
Concrete initiating event (protests in Tunisia) not duplicated elsewhere.
Country-level location (Tunisia) distinct from regional entities.
Region (Middle East) distinct from North Africa and the combined-region reference.
Region (North Africa) distinct from Middle East and the broader combined-region reference.
Event type (overthrow of long-standing dictators) distinct from the role of dictators themselves.
Role/entity class (long-standing dictators) distinct from events affecting them.
Abstract concept (democratic change) clearly unique in this set.
Refers to the combined Middle East and North Africa as a collective region, not identical to either subregion.
Distinct historical political event; no other entity in the group refers to the same event as a whole.
Political organization (faction) clearly distinct from the revolution event, leader, dynasty, or resulting state.
Individual person distinct from the organization, event, dynasty, or state.
Dynasty as a royal family line, distinct from the revolution, organizations, or states mentioned.
Refers to the resulting communist state, which is conceptually distinct from the revolution, its leaders, and the dynasty it overthrew.
Refers specifically to the U.S. civil rights movement as a distinct historical movement; no overlapping entities to merge with.
Clearly denotes the country 'United States'; no other country/location entities present to merge with.
Unambiguously identifies Martin Luther King Jr. as an individual person; no duplicate person entities present.
Unambiguously identifies Rosa Parks as an individual person; no overlapping or duplicate entities.
Represents the general concept of racial segregation; not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Represents the general concept of discrimination; distinct from racial segregation and not duplicated.
Refers collectively to major 1960s U.S. civil rights laws; no other entity in the group represents this same legal category.
Clearly refers to the specific historic document, distinct from the principles it contains.
Represents a specific ideological principle distinct from the document and other abstract rights concepts.
Denotes the general concept of inherent rights, separate from the equality principle and the document itself.
Captures a broader set of ideas influencing later movements, distinct from the specific equality and rights phrases.
Refers to the geographic-historical location of ancient Egypt, distinct from the event taking place there.
Refers to a specific historical labor strike event, which is conceptually separate from the location of ancient Egypt.
Distinct actor group (laborers) involved in the event; no overlap with the physical structures.
Refers to the monumental structures themselves, clearly distinct from the worker group.
Clearly denotes the specific historical event of the French Revolution of 1789, distinct from institutions or principles mentioned.
Refers to the French monarchy as an institution, which is conceptually distinct from both the revolution and the subsequent republic.
Describes the republican form of government established after the revolution, a separate entity from the revolution itself and the prior monarchy.
Captures the ideological principles associated with the revolution and republic, distinct from the political event and institutions.
Refers to the general concept of injustice; although related to oppression, it is a broader and distinct condition, so it should not be merged.
Refers specifically to systemic or prolonged unjust treatment (oppression), which is conceptually related to but not identical with injustice, so it should remain separate.
Refers generically to large-scale uprisings; distinct from the specific American Revolution event and other abstract concepts.
Clearly denotes a specific historical event (American Revolution of 1776) and should not be merged with generic revolutions or abstract goals.
Represents the abstract concept of freedom, distinct from both specific events and the specific political goal of independence from colonial rule.
Denotes a specific political goal (independence from colonial rule), not interchangeable with general freedom or colonial rule as a system.
Describes the governance system of colonial rule itself, conceptually distinct from the goal of independence from it.
Refers specifically to early historical periods and is distinct from the contemporary era; no evidence of duplication with any other entity in the group.
Refers to the contemporary era and is conceptually distinct from ancient times; no indication it should be merged or modified.
Refers specifically to the combined 19th and 20th centuries as a distinct historical period; does not coincide exactly with the other time range.
Refers to a different, later time range (late 20th and early 21st centuries), so it should remain a distinct time-period entity.
Refers specifically to political rights as a subset of rights; distinct from broader rights concepts mentioned elsewhere.
Represents the general collective actors (people) involved in protests; no overlapping entity with same scope to justify merging.
Represents generic rights as an abstract concept; broader than political rights and not identical to 'rights and freedoms'.
Represents the combined notion of rights and freedoms as fundamental entitlements; related to but not identical with the more generic 'rights' entity.
Refers to the condition of injustice, distinct from other concepts mentioned; type and description are consistent.
Refers to the abstract concept of fundamental human rights, clearly distinct from injustice and correctly modeled.
Clearly and correctly refers to the specific social and political movement; no ambiguity or conflict with other entities.
Represents the general phenomenon of police brutality, distinct from the movement, country, or goal entities.
Current description is overly specific to the Black Lives Matter context; updating to a general country description improves reusability.
Correctly captures the abstract goal of racial justice, distinct from specific movements or locations.
Systemic racism is a specific structural condition distinct from other social processes or categories mentioned.
The national conversation on race and inequality is a distinct social process and not the same as race, inequality, or systemic racism themselves.
Race here is a general social category, not reducible to the broader conversation or to inequality as a condition.
Inequality is modeled as a general condition, separate from systemic racism and from the discourse about race and inequality.
All these mentions of 'protests' refer to the same general concept of collective public demonstrations for change, differing only slightly in wording and emphasis.
Refers specifically to the action/tactic of people physically going into the streets to demonstrate, not the broader concept of protests as a whole.
Represents strikes as a distinct protest tactic (work stoppages), conceptually narrower and more specific than the general category of protests.
Denotes peaceful demonstrations as a specific non-violent protest form, not the entire category of protests.
Describes a particular scale/situation—large, widespread protest events—rather than the abstract concept of protests in general.
Represents public demands for reform, which are related to but distinct from the protest actions themselves.
Refers specifically to forceful or armed rebellions, which is a distinct and narrower concept than general protests.
Represents general collective public dissent actions, which can be peaceful or otherwise and are not limited to violent uprisings.
Refers specifically to the phenomenon of repression as a distinct form of control; no clear duplicate in this group.
Refers to violence as a separate phenomenon from repression; they are conceptually related but not identical.
Refers to 'authorities' in a general sense and could include but is not limited to governments; not clearly identical to 'governments' entity.
Refers specifically to governments as formal state institutions; related to but not the same as the broader 'authorities' concept.
Refers specifically to a group of demonstrators advocating democracy, distinct from abstract concepts like dissent or broader political opposition.
Represents an abstract condition or expression of disagreement, not a concrete actor group like the protesters or opposition.
Denotes political or social actors opposing those in power, which is broader and conceptually distinct from the specific group of pro-democracy protesters and from the abstract concept of dissent.
This is an event entity describing a specific government crackdown in Belarus; it is distinct from the country itself.
This is a location entity representing the country Belarus, which is separate from the protest crackdown event.
Distinct historical event; no other candidate refers to the same specific incident.
Country-level location entity; clearly distinct from the event and not duplicated in the group.
Distinct collective-actor concept (non-elite individuals) separate from abstract attributes or norms.
Abstract normative concept clearly different from people as actors or their psychological attributes.
Specific human attribute (resilience) that is conceptually distinct from determination, even if often co-mentioned.
Specific human attribute (determination) that is related to but not identical with resilience, so should remain separate.
Refers to an abstract concept of human resilience and determination, distinct from the goal state described by 'better world'.
Represents a future aspirational societal condition, not the same concept as the 'human spirit' that motivates achieving it.
Social justice is modeled as a broader abstract social ideal about fair and equitable social arrangements, distinct from but related to equality.
Equality is a specific abstract condition of equal rights and status; it is related to but not identical with social justice, so it should remain a separate entity.
Refers specifically to the U.S. civil rights movement, distinct from generic plural movements mentioned in other entries.
Denotes general movements for democracy, a broad category separate from the specific U.S. civil rights movement and from other themed movements.
Represents generic movements for equality, conceptually distinct from democracy and justice movements and not tied to a single historical movement.
Refers to general movements for justice, a separate conceptual category from democracy and equality movements and from the specific U.S. civil rights movement.
Represents the general concept of political and social revolutions; not identical to any of the more specific related entities.
Refers specifically to socialist movements inspired by the Russian Revolution, distinct from generic revolutions or specific uprisings.
Denotes particular uprisings worldwide influenced by the Russian Revolution, not the same as the abstract concept of revolutions or socialist movements.
Describes oppressive regimes as targets of these movements and uprisings, a distinct class of political institutions rather than events or movements.
Distinct abstract concept referring to the overall configuration of political systems across multiple countries; not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Represents human societies as collective actors affected by events; no other entity in the group shares this scope or role.
Clearly denotes a type/category of collective events (protests and revolutions) and is not redundant with the other abstract or actor entities.
Refers to the global location/context; semantically distinct from societies, events, or political landscape concepts in the group.
Distinct abstract concept referring to the overall trajectory of human events; not synonymous with the other entities.
In this context, 'change' clearly refers to societal/political change from protests and revolutions, so the name and type_hint should be made more specific to avoid ambiguity with generic change.
Here 'transformation' denotes profound societal/political shifts from collective action; clarifying the scope and marking it as an outcome reduces ambiguity with generic transformation.
Already clearly defined as an outcome related to protests and revolutions; distinct but closely related to the other concepts and does not require modification.
Refers broadly to the recorded past of protests and revolutions, which is distinct from both their legacy and the metaphorical road to progress.
A metaphorical process (path toward social and political advancement) that is conceptually different from any specific history or legacy of protests.
Focuses on the enduring impact and consequences of past protests and revolutions, which is related to but not identical with the broader history or the road-to-progress metaphor.
Distinct historical movement; no other entity in the group represents the same concept.
Represents a specific calendar year; no duplicate time entities are present.
Specific triggering event within Tunisia; not duplicated by any other entry.
Country-level location entity; clearly distinct from regional entities and pronoun-like references.
Regional location (Middle East) that is conceptually distinct and not duplicated.
Regional location (North Africa) that is conceptually distinct and not duplicated.

Role entity for authoritarian leaders; not the same as the overthrow event type.
Abstract political concept; no overlap with other entities.
Refers to the combined Middle East and North Africa as a collective; not identical to either region entity alone, so should remain separate.
Distinct movement entity (U.S. civil rights movement) with clear scope and description; no duplicates present.
Country-level location entity; not redundant with any other entry.

Unique person entity for Rosa Parks clearly distinct from all others.
Concept of racial segregation is distinct from general discrimination and other entities.

Represents a collective concept (1960s landmark civil rights legislation) distinct from the movement and other entities.
Distinct geographic-historical entity (civilization/location) separate from workers, structures, actions, or demands.
Refers specifically to a group of laborers, conceptually distinct from the pyramids, the strike event, and the demands.
Refers to physical monumental structures, distinct from the workers, strike, and demands.
Represents a specific collective action/event (the strike), not the workers, location, or demands themselves.
Represents one of the demands (improved conditions), conceptually distinct from wages and from the strike event itself.
Represents a separate economic demand (compensation) distinct from working conditions and other entities.
Refers to a specific broad social discourse event/process, distinct from the underlying concepts of race or inequality.
Refers to the general social category of race, which is conceptually distinct from both inequality and the specific national conversation.
Refers to the general condition of inequality, which is distinct from the category of race and from the particular national conversation.
Movements for democracy are conceptually distinct from movements for equality or justice, focusing specifically on democratic governance.
Movements for equality emphasize reducing social and political inequality and are not identical to democracy or justice movements.
Movements for justice center on fairness and rectifying wrongs, which is related but distinct from democracy and equality movements.

Both mentions describe the same abstract social ideal of equal rights and opportunities, framed as a core goal of justice movements; the type difference (AbstractConcept vs Goal) reflects context rather than distinct entities.
Distinct historical event with clear description and context; no conflicting entities to merge with.
Refers specifically to the country China, clearly distinct from other entities.

General actor group (opposition), distinct from governments and protesters.
The description and plural form indicate a collective of state actors rather than a single actor, so ActorGroup is more accurate.
Refers to a general collective of non-elite individuals; distinct concept with no overlapping identity with other entities in the group.
Refers to the abstract normative concept of accountability, clearly different from the actor group 'ordinary people'.
Refers to a broad early historical period and is distinct from the other, more specific time ranges.
Denotes the contemporary era, clearly different from the historical centuries mentioned in the other entities.
Specifically covers the 19th and 20th centuries, a distinct and well-bounded historical period.
Refers to the late 20th and early 21st centuries, overlapping but not identical to the 19th and 20th centuries, so should remain separate.
Distinct political event (the 1789 French Revolution) clearly separate from the institutions and principles it affected.
Refers specifically to the monarchical system in France, a political institution distinct from the revolution and the later republic.
Refers to the republican form of government established after the monarchy, distinct from both the revolution itself and the monarchy it replaced.
Represents an ideological slogan/principles, clearly different in nature from the political events and institutions mentioned.
This clearly and uniquely refers to the U.S. Declaration of Independence as a specific historical document.
This is a distinct ideological principle (the equality phrase) referenced within, but not identical to, the Declaration of Independence.
This denotes the abstract concept of inherent rights, which is separate from both the document and the equality phrase.
This describes a broader set of principles influencing later movements and is conceptually distinct from the specific equality phrase and unalienable rights.
Refers to a specific historical political event, distinct from any person; no overlapping identity with other entities.
Refers to a specific historical person (leader of the Bolsheviks), clearly distinct from the Russian Revolution event.
The Bolsheviks are clearly a political organization distinct from the state they established, so this entity should remain separate.
The 'world's first communist state' refers to the post-revolution state entity, which is conceptually distinct from the Bolshevik organization and should not be merged.
Refers specifically to political or social repression as a distinct phenomenon from other terms.
Denotes physical violence as a separate phenomenon from repression and authorities.
Represents state or governmental actors, a different type and concept from the phenomena of repression and violence.
Represents the general concept of injustice, which is related to but not identical with oppression.
Represents the specific condition of oppression, distinct from broader injustice even though they are conceptually related.
All three refer to the same general concept of public protest demonstrations, differing only in scale (widespread) or framing (general vs event) but not in underlying meaning.
“Taking to the streets” denotes a specific form or tactic of protest rather than the general concept of protests, so it should remain distinct.
“Strikes” are a specific protest tactic involving work stoppages, conceptually related to but distinct from general protests.
“Peaceful demonstrations” specify a non-violent subtype of protest and thus represent a narrower concept than general protests.
“Calls for reform” describes demands for change, which are related outcomes or components of protest movements but conceptually distinct from the protests themselves.
Distinct concept referring to authoritarian governments; no other entity in the group shares this specific meaning.
Describes a specific type of collective action (rebellions), clearly different from regimes or abstract authority.
Represents an abstract notion of established power, not a regime or an uprising, so it should remain separate.
Refers specifically to political rights as a distinct category of rights; no overlapping entity with the same scope.
Refers broadly to groups of individuals participating in protests; no other entity in the group denotes the same actor concept.
Represents rights in a general sense, which is broader than political rights; should remain distinct and not merged.

Refers specifically to revolutionary movements across Europe and beyond inspired by the French Revolution, a distinct subset concept rather than generic revolutions.
Denotes socialist movements emerging after the Russian Revolution, which are a specific ideological subset of movements, not identical to the general notion of revolutions.
Represents specific uprisings around the world influenced by the Russian Revolution, which are distinct concrete events rather than the generic concept of revolutions.
Describes oppressive regimes as political institutions targeted by movements and uprisings, clearly a different ontological category from the events themselves.
Refers to the general class of events (protests and revolutions) shaping political landscapes, distinct from their history or legacy.
Specifically denotes the historical record of protests and revolutions, conceptually separate from the events themselves or their legacy.
A metaphorical process ('road to progress'), not the same as protests, their history, or their legacy.
Represents the lasting impact ('legacy') of protests and revolutions, distinct from both the events and their recorded history.
Distinct, well-defined historical event; no other entity refers to the same event, so no merge or modification is needed.
Represents an abstract concept (freedom) that is clearly different from the historical event; should remain a separate entity.
Represents a political goal or aspiration (independence), distinct from the governance system it opposes.
Describes a governance system (colonial rule) rather than the goal of independence from it, so it should remain a separate entity.
Resilience and determination are related but distinct human attributes; this entry specifically captures resilience and should remain separate.
This entity captures determination as a distinct attribute from resilience, so it should not be merged and should be kept as-is.
Refers to an abstract concept of resilience and determination; no other entity describes the same notion.
Represents a distinct goal state or envisioned future society, clearly different from the concept of human spirit.
This is an abstract concept about political systems across countries and is distinct from any geographic or physical location.
This refers to the global physical and social context ('the world') and is clearly different from an abstract political configuration concept.
All three refer to substantially the same outcome—changes or transformations in social and political structures—differing only in phrasing, not in concept.
Refers to the broad trajectory of human events over time, which is distinct from specific instances of social or political change.
Represents human communities (societies) as collective actors affected by change, which is conceptually different from the outcomes of social or political change.
Represents the location/era (ancient Egypt) distinct from other entities like workers, pyramids, or the strike event.

Represents a specific type of demand (better working conditions) distinct from wages and from the protest event itself.
Refers to wages as an economic concept and demand, distinct from working conditions and other entities.

Country-level location (Tunisia) with no other entity representing the same country.

Region-level location (North Africa) distinct from Middle East and the combined region reference.
Event type describing a class of events (overthrow of dictators), not duplicated elsewhere.
Role-type entity (long-standing dictators) distinct from the events describing their overthrow.
Abstract concept (democratic change) with no overlapping abstract concept entities.

Distinct political event; no other entity in the group refers to the overall revolution itself.
A political organization (Bolsheviks) clearly distinct from the revolution, its leader, the dynasty, and the resulting state.
A specific person (Vladimir Lenin) distinct from the organization, event, dynasty, and state.
A royal dynasty clearly separate from the revolution event, political organization, person, and new state.
Refers to the resulting communist state, which is conceptually distinct from the revolution, the Bolsheviks, Lenin, and the Romanov dynasty.
Distinct, specific historical document; no other entity in the group refers to the same artifact.
Represents a specific ideological principle quoted from the Declaration, not the document itself or other concepts.
Denotes the abstract concept of inherent rights, distinct from both the document and the equality principle.
Refers to a broader set of principles influencing later movements, not identical to any single quoted phrase or the document.

Canonical country entity; no alternative mentions or ambiguity in this group.
Specific social system targeted by the movement, distinct from other entities and correctly typed.
General concept of unfair treatment; distinct from racial segregation and adequately described.
Distinct, well-identified historical person with clear description and correct type.
Distinct, well-identified historical person separate from other entities, with accurate description and type.
Refers to a category of U.S. civil rights laws in the 1960s, not the same as the people mentioned; no duplicate present to merge with.
Distinct historical event (the American Revolution) with clear temporal and geographic scope, not overlapping with any other entity in the group.
Abstract concept of freedom, broader than and not identical to independence or the specific historical event.
Represents a specific political goal (independence from colonial rule), conceptually distinct from general freedom and from colonial rule itself.
Denotes a governance system (colonial rule), clearly different in type and meaning from the other entities.
"Ancient times" is a distinct, broad historical period and does not overlap specifically with the more recent, bounded centuries listed.
"Present day" refers to the contemporary era and is clearly distinct from the historical century-based periods.
"19th and 20th centuries" is a well-defined and separate historical period from ancient times, late 20th/early 21st, and present day.
"Late 20th and early 21st centuries" is a specific overlapping-but-distinct period from "19th and 20th centuries" and should remain separate.
Repression is a distinct political/social phenomenon separate from violence and authorities, with an accurate description and type.
Violence is a separate phenomenon from repression and is correctly captured as physical force causing harm or intimidation.
